author: R Krishnamoorthy
text:
Streets of residential localities are turning unsafe for walkers, due to the increase in numbers of stray dogs.

Packs of dogs fighting amongst themselves and causing disturbance to passers-by are becoming quite visible on the roadsides in the vicinity of garbage bins, in places such as Soorampatti Valasu, Kasipalayam, Moolapalayam and surrounding localities.

Earlier this week, the Supreme Court on Wednesday directed the States and the local bodies to sterilise and vaccinate nuisance-causing stray dogs, under the provisions of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act. The Supreme Court has specified that the compassion for animals and existence of human beings must be balanced, and that the scope for spread of rabies must be eliminated through controlling the dog population.

There have been several instances of ward councillors making repeated representations to the civic body to deal with the menace in right earnest.

According to a councillor, the funding was not sufficient for vaccinating dogs. The Supreme Court had, late last year, permitted local bodies to eliminate street dogs suffering from incurable ailments.

In recent years, Mission Rabies was carried out in Erode under the aegis of Indian Project for Animals and Nature (IPAN) and People for Animals (PfA) Coimbatore Unit 2. Erode, according to IPAN records, is one of the 12 worst-affected areas due to dog bites in the country.

However, even troublesome dogs cannot be culled. The NGOs involved in birth control programs are required to bring back the dogs to their original location after neutering and vaccination.

According to veterinary experts, vaccinated dogs not only lose capacity to breed, but also shed aggressive behaviour.
title: Stray dogs pose a threat to residents in Erode
